awd_titl_txt: Convergence QL:Workshop on Quantum Elements of Secure Communication
awd_abstract_narration: This workshop brings together researchers to discuss current topics and trends in quantum communications. This meeting addresses a central issue belonging to the NSF's Quantum Leap Big Idea, related to development of secure and scalable modes of communication based on quantum phenomena. Participants come from a diverse pool of convergent disciplines, ranging from chemistry, materials sciences, engineering to physics and quantum information. A post-meeting report is planned to summarize the current status and challenges in the field. Members of underrepresented groups and minorities will be encouraged to apply.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

inst.inst_name: Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University

por.por_cntn:
The development of the science and technology required to build realistic quantum networks for communication and computation will be accelerated by a convergent approach that brings together researchers with diverse expertise, including in single-photon sources, optical networks, quantum control theory, systems engineering, etc. The goal of this project was to address this need and advance the field of secure quantum communications by bringing together leading experts from these diverse disciplines to brainstorm about and collaborate on a convergent path toward the development of quantum networks. This project supported two workshops, one in 2017 and another in 2023, to accomplish this goal. Both workshops took place at the Virginia Tech Research Center in Arlington, Virginia.

 

The workshop in 2017 took place over three days and had more than 40 participants, including experts in the field. There was a limited number of talks representing leading experts with diverse backgrounds. The participants came from Physics, Engineering, Chemistry and Mathematics. National lab and funding agencies were also represented. The workshop allocated significant amount of time each day for discussions and brainstorming sessions. The conclusions from the workshop were collected and written up by the PIs. The Executive Summary has been shared with NSF Program Officers. 

 

The objectives of the workshop were to survey the status of quantum communication and optical/photonic quantum computing and lay out a vision for a future multi-purpose quantum network that would simultaneously realize applications such as a secure quantum internet and distributed quantum information processing. The participants of the workshop were asked to identify key challenges in realizing quantum technologies and discuss strategies to ensure US competitiveness in a future quantum economy.

 

A main conclusion was that a convergent, multidisciplinary approach is necessary to overcome these challenges and that there is a critical need for a national initiative and significant federal investment to drive breakthroughs in the field. Such a nationwide initiative should broadly involve the major funding agencies, national and government labs, and industry. The NSF in particular can play an important role in funding large-scale, longer-term, multi-investigator programs that incentivize the convergence of diverse expertise to solve outstanding basic science challenges in this field while maintaining a vision toward applications. The education and interdisciplinary training of the future quantum workforce should be an integral part of such efforts, as there is already a high demand from industry for scientists possessing the requisite broad knowledge base.

 

In 2023, the PIs organized a workshop for researchers working on quantum interconnects. All the teams funded by the NSF QuIC-TAQS program were invited and all teams (except for one) had representatives. This workshop brought together researchers from different disciplines (engineering, physics, math, etc) and different expertise (theory vs experiment) to discuss the status of quantum interconnects. Students from each team were also involved and presented posters. One conclusion from the workshop was that moderately sized grants that support teams of 4-5 PIs for a period of 4-5 years are especially effective in advancing the field.
